The SRAS curve is the short-run aggregate supply curve, which represents the relationship between the price level and the quantity of output that firms are willing to produce in the short run, assuming that the prices of inputs remain constant. The SRAS curve is generally upward-sloping, meaning that an increase in the price level will lead to an increase in the quantity of output supplied, all else equal.

The NK Phillips curve is a curve that represents the relationship between inflation and the degree of economic slack in the economy, and it is named after economists Thomas J. Sargent and Lars Peter Hansen and Nobel laureate Christopher A. Sims. The curve is typically downward-sloping, which means that as unemployment falls, inflation tends to rise. It is a key feature of the New Keynesian macroeconomic model, which emphasizes the importance of sticky prices and wages in the short run.

The SRAS curve and the NK Phillips curve are related concepts in macroeconomics, but they are not the same thing. The SRAS curve represents the short-run behavior of firms in response to changes in the price level, while the NK Phillips curve represents the relationship between inflation and unemployment in the economy.
